metadata.title: Enhanced activity of microwave-activated CoO<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>/MOR catalyst for the epoxidation of α-pinene with air

Fig. 1 XRD patterns of CoOx/MOR catalysts. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 IR spectra of MOR and CoOx/MOR catalysts. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 TG curves of MOR and 7%CoOx/MOR samples. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 SEM images of MOR and CoOx/MOR materials. (a: MOR, b: 3%CoOx/MOR, c: 7%CoOx/MOR, d: 10%CoOx/MOR). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 TEM image and particle size distribution of MOR and CoOx/MOR materials. (a: MOR, b: 1%CoOx/MOR, c: 3%CoOx/MOR, d: 5%CoOx/MOR, e: 7%CoOx/MOR, f: 10%CoOx/MOR). Fig. 5 Fig. 6 N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms (a) and pore size distributions (b) of MOR and 7%CoOx/MOR. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 XPS spectra of 7%CoOx/MOR: (a) wide spectrum, (b) Co 2p1/2, (c) Co 2p3/2. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 H2-TPR profiles of MOR and 7%CoOx/MOR. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Effect of Co contents on the epoxidation of α-pinene. (Reaction conditions: α-Pinene, 6 mmol; Catalyst, 100 mg; CHP, 0.6 mmol; Time: 4 h ; Temperature, 90 °C; DMF, 10 g; Flowrate of air, 40 mL/min). Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Influence of reaction time on the epoxidation of α-pinene. (Reaction conditions: α-Pinene, 6 mmol; Catalyst, 100 mg; CHP, 0.6 mmol; Temperature, 90 °C; DMF, 10 g; Flowrate of air, 40 mL/min). Fig. 10 Table 1 Structural parameters of MOR and 7%CoOx/MOR. Table 1 Samples BET surface area (m2/g) Pore volume (cm3/g) Pore diameter (nm) MOR 319.5 0.162 8.44 3%CoOx/MOR 296.7 0.146 8.44 7%CoOx/MOR 268.2 0.129 8.44 10%CoOx/MOR 250.4 0.112 8.44 Table 2 Catalytic epoxidation of α-pinene over various cobalt-based catalysts. Table 2 Entry Catalyst Conversion(mol%) Epoxide selectivity (%) 1 7%CoOx/MOR 92.7 87.6 2 7%CoOx/beta 87.6 89.7 3 7%CoOx/Y 84.2 80.4 4 7%CoOx/ZSM-5 73.7 92.2 5 7%CoOx/13X 81.4 85.0 6 7%CoOx/MCM-22 58.7 97.5 7 7%CoOx/SBA-15 23.6 85.2 8 7%CoOx/SiO2 35.1 84.4 Reaction conditions: catalyst, 100 mg; α-Pinene, 6 mmol; CHP, 0.6 mmol; DMF, 10 g; flowrate of air, 40 mL/min; temperature, 90 °C; Time, 4 h. Table 3 Catalytic epoxidation of α-pinene over various metal-based catalysts. Table 3 Entry Catalyst Metal salts Conversion(mol%) Epoxide selectivity(%) 1 7%CoOx/MOR Cobalt acetate 92.7 87.6 2 7%FeOx/MOR Ferric chloride 13.6 93.8 3 7%NiO/MOR Nickel nitrate 6.1 89.7 4 7%CuO/MOR Cupric nitrate 13.7 100 5 7%CrOx/MOR Chromic acetate 20.1 97.0 6 7%MnOx/MOR Manganese acetate 6.9 85.0 Reaction conditions: α-Pinene, 6 mmol; Catalyst, 100 mg; Initiator, 0.6 mmol; Time:4 h ; Temperature, 90 °C; DMF, 10 g; Flowrate of air, 40 mL/min. Table 4 Effect of synthesis methods on the epoxidation of α-pinene. Table 4 Entry Catalyst Synthesis methods Conversion(mol%) Epoxide selectivity(%) 1 7%CoOx+MOR Mixed 63.4 91.9 2 7%Co-MOR Ion exchange 83.3 97.2 3 7%CoOx/MOR Impregnation 92.7 87.6 4 7%CoOx/MORa Impregnation 64.2 95.8 Reaction conditions: α-Pinene, 6 mmol; Catalyst, 100 mg; Initiator, 0.6 mmol; Time:4 h ; Temperature, 90 °C; DMF, 10 g; Flowrate of air, 40 mL/min. a: Traditional heating. Table 5 Effect of various solvents on the epoxidation of α-pinene. Table 5 Entry Catalyst Solvent Conversion(mol%) Epoxide selectivity(%) 1 7%CoOx/MOR toluene 6.3 100 2 DMF 92.7 87.6 3 acetyl acetone 6.0 99.9 4 1,4-dioxane 2.7 93.6 5 cyclohexanone 20.7 8.5 6 tetrachloroethane 53.1 0 7 butyl acetate 31.0 37.4 Reaction conditions: α-Pinene, 6 mmol; Catalyst, 100 mg; CHP, 0.6 mmol; Time: 4 h ; Temperature, 90 °C; Solvent, 10 g; Flowrate of air, 40 mL/min. Table 6 Effect of initiator on the epoxidation of α-pinene. Table 6 Entry Catalyst Initiator Conversion(mol%) Epoxide selectivity(%) 1 7%CoOx/MOR air 64.9 96.4 2 O2 49.8 89.6 3 CHP 15.7 98.9 4 TBHP 17.8 93.2 5 CHP + O2 55.7 82.9 6 CHP + air 92.7 87.6 7 TBHP + air 82.9 95.2 8 α-epoxy pinane + air 73.7 92.9 Reaction conditions: α-Pinene, 6 mmol; Catalyst, 100 mg; Initiator, 0.6 mmol; Time: 4 h ; Temperature, 90 °C; DMF, 10 g; Flowrate of air, 40 mL/min. Table 7 The epoxidation of various olefins with air over 7%CoOx/MOR. Enhanced activity of microwave-activated CoOx/MOR catalyst for the epoxidation of α-pinene with air Peipei Tao a b Xinhuan Lu a b ⁎ Haifu Zhang a b Run Jing a b Fengfeng Huang a b Sha Wu a b Dan Zhou a b Qinghua Xia a b ⁎ a Hubei Collaborative Innovation Center for Advanced Organic Chemical Materials, Hubei University, Wuhan 430062, PR China Hubei Collaborative Innovation Center for Advanced Organic Chemical Materials Hubei University Wuhan 430062 PR China b Ministry-of-Education Key Laboratory for the Synthesis and Application of Organic Functional Molecules, Hubei University, Wuhan 430062, PR China Ministry-of-Education Key Laboratory for the Synthesis and Application of Organic Functional Molecules Hubei University Wuhan 430062 PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors at: Hubei Collaborative Innovation Center for Advanced Organic Chemical Materials, Hubei University, Wuhan 430062, PR China. Hubei Collaborative Innovation Center for Advanced Organic Chemical Materials Hubei University Wuhan 430062 PR China Graphical abstract CoOx species is firstly introduced onto MOR by microwave heating impregnation to catalyze the epoxidation of α-pinene with air. The conversion of α-pinene over 7%CoOx/MOR prepared by microwave heating reaches 92.7 mol% in 4 h at 90 °C, which is nearly 1.5 times that of the catalyst by traditional heating. CoOx species is firstly introduced onto MOR (Mordenite) by impregnation with microwave heating to catalyze the epoxidation of α-pinene with air. The obtained samples have been characterized by X-ray diffraction, FTIR, SEM, TEM, BET surface area, porosity by N2 adsorption. 7%CoOx/MOR catalyst exhibits remarkably higher activity and selectivity in the epoxidation of α-pinene than that prepared by traditional heating impregnation. The epoxidation conversion of α-pinene over 7%CoOx/MOR prepared by microwave heating reaches 92.7 mol% in 4 h at 90 °C, which is nearly 1.5 times that of the catalyst by traditional impregnation. This is due to the fact that CoOx nanoparticles are produced by microwave heating and uniformly dispersed on MOR. Keywords Microwave heating CoOx/MOR α-Pinene Epoxidation Air 1 Introduction The development of science and industry has led people to look for new markets for microwave energy. Since microwave heating was discovered in the 1940s, microwaves have been widely used in various fields, including chemistry [1,2]. Due to the difference of microwave heating from conventional heating, the use of microwave energy to heat chemical reactions is becoming more frequently [3]. In order to use microwave energy to heat organic solvents safely, various aspects of this field have also been studied [4]. Microwave heating does have a very high attractiveness for chemical reactions and is also accepted widely [5]. The principle of microwave heating is that some polar liquids and solids absorb electromagnetic energy and convert the absorbed electromagnetic energy into heat. The above statement has also been validated through publications in recent years [6]. Microwave heating can greatly shorten the reaction time, improve the product yield and solve the problem of uneven heating [7]. Compared to traditional heating, microwave heating has a greater advantage. When traditional heating is used, it takes longer time to reach the temperature needed; however, microwave heating can quickly reach the temperature we set [8]. Of course, microwaves are cleaner and more economical than traditional heating methods [9]. In the meantime, the heating method is different. Traditional heating conveys the heat to the surface of the material by convection or conduction, while microwave heating heats the material by converting electromagnetic energy into thermal energy [2]. In one word, microwave heating can reduce the reaction time but increase the yield of the product. More importantly, it is in line with the development of green chemistry programs. Now, mature microwave technology is more and more widely applied [10]. Considering its advantages, microwaves are introduced into the catalysis process. In 1986, microwave-assisted organic synthesis was first reported [11]. There have existed many reports on the use of microwave heating to treat organic synthesis and catalytic reactions [12–17]. Selectively catalytic epoxidation of olefins is an important industrial reaction because epoxides play an important role in organic synthesis [18–20]. There are many oxygen sources for the reaction with olefins. Previously used methods include peracid and halohydrin ones, in which the used oxidants were mainly consisted of peracetic acid, iodosyl, organic peroxide and hypochlorite [21–25]. Hypochlorite can give a relatively high yield, but produces a lot of pollutants and increases the cost of post-treatment. Iodosyl and peracetic acid also have safety and environment problems. Hydrogen peroxide as oxidant will cause relatively high cost of production with some safety problems during transport, although the product is non-polluting. Therefore, molecular oxygen or air as oxidant still has a great advantage [26–29]. This is that molecular oxygen or air is cheap and readily available, very clean and environmentally friendly [30–32]. In this work, CoOx species is firstly loaded onto MOR by impregnation with microwave heating to catalyze the epoxidation of α-pinene with air. As the comparison, CoOx/beta, CoOx/Y, CoOx/ZSM-5, CoOx/13X, CoOx/MCM-22, CoOx/SBA-15 and CoOx/SiO2 catalysts are also prepared under the same conditions. The catalyst 7%CoOx/MOR synthesized by microwave-assisted heating shows an enhanced activity. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials All reagents and materials used for epoxidation of olefins were not purified further. The reagents and materials included Co(Ac)2·4H2O (≥99.0%,Aladdin), Co(NO3)2·6H2O (98%,Tianjin), CoSO4·7H2O (99.5%, Tianjin), CoCl2·6H2O (≥98%, Tianjin), FeCl3·10H2O (≥99.5%, Sinopharm), Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (>98%, Tianjin), Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (>99.5%, Tianjin), Cr(Ac)2·2H2O (>98%, Tianjin), Mn(Ac)2·4H2O (>99.5%, Tianjin), Na-MOR (Nankai), Na-Beta (Nankai), Na-Y (Nankai), Na-ZSM-5 (Nankai), Na-13X (Nankai), MCM-22 (Nankai), SBA-15 (self-made), SiO2 (99.9%, Degussa), Al2O3 (99%, Tianjin), toluene (≥98.5%, Sinopharm), DMF (≥98.5%, Sinopharm), DMA (≥98.5%, Sinopharm), acetyl acetone (≥99%, Sinopharm), 1,4-dioxane (≥99.5%, Sinopharm), cyclohexanone (≥98%, Sinopharm), tetrachloroethane (≥98.5%, Sinopharm), butyl acetate (≥99.5%, Sinopharm), CHP (≥72%, Sinopharm), TBHP (≥65%, Sinopharm), α-epoxy pinane (≥95%, Tokyo), α-pinene (>98.0%, Aladdin), β-pinene (>98.0%, Aladdin), cyclohexene (>99%, Aladdin), styrene(≥98.5%, Sinopharm), α-methyl styrene (99%, Aladdin), 1-decene (≥95%, Aladdin), 1-dodecene (≥95%, Aladdin), 1,5-cyclooctadiene (≥99%, Aladdin), limonene (>99%, Aladdin), dicyclopentadiene (≥97%, Aladdin). 2.2 Preparation of catalysts Zeolites (Na-MOR (Mordenite zeolite), Na-Beta, Na-Y, Na-ZSM-5, Na-13X, MCM-22 and SBA-15) and SiO2 were commercial products. Co2+ cations or other transition metal ions were introduced into zeolites by impregnation and heated by microwave, i.e. 2.0 g zeolite was heated by microwave at 90 °C for 4 h with an aqueous solution (50 mL) containing 2.4 mmol of Co(Ac)2·4H2O or other salts like FeCl3·10H2O, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, Cr(Ac)3·2H2O and Mn(Ac)2·4H2O. The solid powder was recovered by rotary evaporation and followed by drying at 100 °C for 8 h, which was then placed in a crucible and calcined at desired temperature in an air atmosphere for 3 h. The obtained powder solids were denoted as 7%CoOx/MOR, 7%CoOx/beta, 7%CoOx/Y, 7%CoOx/ZSM-5, 7%CoOx/13X, 7%CoOx/MCM-22, 7%CoOx/SBA-15 and 7%CoOx/SiO2. The other obtained solids were denoted as 7%FeOx/MOR, 7%NiO/MOR, 7%CuO/MOR, 7%CrOx/MOR and 7%MnOx/MOR. 2.3 Characterization of catalytic materials Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Bruker D8A25 diffractometer with Cu Kα (λ = 1.54184 Å) operating at 40 kV and 40 mA from 2θ = 5 to 80°. FT-IR spectra of framework vibrations were recorded on a Perkin Elmer Spectrum One FTIR spectrophotometer in the range of 400-4000 cm−1. UV–vis spectra of samples were recorded on a Shimadzu UV-2550 spectrometer. The powdered sample was loaded into a quartz cell, and the spectra were collected in the range of 200–800 nm referenced to BaSO4. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of the catalysts was performed on a Mettler Toledo TGA/SDTA851e under N2 flowing of 40 mL/min at a heating rate of 10 °C/min up to 800 °C. The morphology and size of the sample was imaged on a JEOL JSM-6510 A scanning electron microscope (SEM). TEM images were obtained using FEI Tecnai G20 at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms were determined by QuantachromeiQ-MP gas adsorption analyzer. The BET surface area was calculated based on the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation; the pore distribution and total pore volume was calculated by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms were determined by QuantachromeiQ-MP gas adsorption analyzer. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer PHI ESCA system. TPR experiments s conducted from room temperature to 700 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min using a thermo-conductive detector (TCD) mounted on a TP-5076 TPD/TPR analyzer. 2.4 Catalytic epoxidation reactions The epoxidation of alkenes with air was performed in a 50-ml two-necked flat-bottomed glass flask equipped with a cryogenic-liquid condenser under atmospheric pressure. Typically, 6 mmol of α-pinene, 0.6 mmol of CHP, 10 g of DMF and 100 mg of catalyst were added into the reactor. The mixture was stirred vigorously by a magnetic stirrer and heated in microwave reactor to 90 °C. Then 40 ml/min of air was introduced into the bottom of reactor by bubbling. The reaction was continued for several hours while stirring vigorously. After the completion of the reaction, the liquid products were separated by centrifugation and analyzed by a gas chromatograph FL9720 equipped with a capillary column (Rtx@-5, 30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm) and an FID detector, where used chlorobenzene as the internal standard. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural characterizations Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of CoOx/MOR catalysts with different amounts of cobalt, in which the content of Co is determined by ICP. It can be found that the framework structure of MOR remains unchanged after being treated by the impregnation method. Meanwhile, there is no characteristic diffraction peak of the CoOx, indicating that CoOx still retains amorphous state and is highly dispersed on MOR. As the cobalt content increases, the intensity of diffraction peaks of MOR gradually decreases, ascribed to the blocking effect of the supported Co species. Fig. 2 shows the IR spectra of MOR and CoOx/MOR. From the IR spectra of CoOx/MOR with different Co contents, we can see that the characteristic absorption peak at 1087 cm−1 belongs to SiOSi tetrahedral asymmetrical stretching vibration, at 802 cm−1 attributed to SiO tetrahedral stretching vibration, and at 463 cm−1 to the bending vibration of the Si-O bond. The infrared spectra of MOR and CoOx/MOR show the unchanged framework structure of MOR molecular sieve after being loaded with cobalt oxide, consistent with the XRD results. Fig. S1 shows the UV–vis spectra of all the samples tested under the same conditions. It is known from the literature that the maximum absorption peak of Co(Ac)2·4H2O is at 515 nm [33]. For CoOx/MOR, two new UV absorption peaks appear at about 415 nm and 710 nm, similar to the UV–vis spectrum of Co3O4 [34]. Therefore, it can be speculated that the oxidation state of cobalt in CoOx/MOR samples may exist in the form of CoII/CoIII coexistence. In addition, as the cobalt content increases, the intensity of ultraviolet absorption peak also gradually increases. Fig. 3 shows the thermal stability curves for MOR and 7%CoOx/MOR. As can be seen from the Fig. 3, the weight loss in the first stage occurs at 30–250 °C due to the loss of adsorbed water. The weight loss of MOR and 7%CoOx/MOR is about 9.49 wt% and 11.67 wt%, respectively. From 251 to 600 °C, there is no significant weight loss for MOR, but about 2.31% weight loss for 7%CoOx/MOR, may be ascribed to the decomposition of a small amount of Co3O4 in the catalyst to generate CoO. The surface morphology of MOR and CoOx/MOR materials are investigated by SEM. From Fig. 4 (a), we can see that the MOR surface is relatively smooth. Although the cobalt loading is 3%, no obvious cobalt particles can be seen from Fig. 4(b). When the Co loading content is further increased to 7% (Fig. 4(c)), we can see very obvious CoOx particles with an average size of 5.84 nm, which are uniformly dispersed on the MOR surface. This may contribute to high activity of CoOx/MOR in the epoxidation of α-pinene, i.e. the proper Co loading allows the active sites utilized more fully. When the Co content is increased to 10% (Fig. 4(d)), more CoOx particles are observed, some of which are stacked. The increase of the cobalt content results in gradual increase of the average particle size of CoOx, also confirmed by TEM. As shown in Fig. 5 , TEM analysis further shows the surface morphology and particle size of the catalysts. The CoOx particles are almost invisible on the surface of molecular sieve with a low Co loading of 1% (Fig. 5(b)). 3%CoOx/MOR and 5%CoOx/MOR contain CoOx particles with an average particle size of 4.81 nm (Fig. 5(c)) and 5.82 nm (Fig. 5(d)), respectively. The average diameter of CoOx observed by TEM is 5.84 nm for 7%CoOx/MOR (Fig. 5(e)), while the average particle size of CoOx is about 6.89 nm for 10%CoOx/MOR (Fig. 5(f)). This result confirms that the average particle size of CoOx gradually increases as the cobalt content increases. BET surface area, pore volume and pore size distribution of the samples can be obtained by N2 adsorption-desorption. As shown in Fig. 6 , both MOR and 7%CoOx/MOR show type IV adsorption-desorption isotherms with a pronounced hysteresis loop, indicative of the existence of mesoporous pores. Compared with MOR, the average pore diameter of CoOx/MOR remains basically unchanged. Obviously, as the cobalt content increases, BET surface area and pore volume of thus-synthesized samples gradually decrease. This may be due to the formation of larger particles of cobalt oxide that blocks the micropores of molecular sieve. The surface constituents and chemical states of 7%CoOx/MOR catalyst are further investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (Fig. 7 ). The component O1 at 533.4 eV is attributed to the multiplicity of physisorbed and chemisorbed water on or near the surface. The O2 at 531.7 eV is usually associated with oxygen in OH― groups. And the O3 sitting at 529.7 eV is typical of metal oxygen bonds [35]. The splitting spectrum of Co(2p) is shown below. We assign a peak around 780.82 eV to the CoIII 3/2 configuration, and the other peak around 782.1 eV to the CoII 3/2 configuration. The small peak at 786.6 eV is Co2+ shake-up satellite peak. The other small peaks at 789.4 eV are Co3+ shake-up satellite ones. This is because low-spin Co3+ cations can only induce weaker satellite characteristics than high-spin Co2+ [36,37]. The above results show that both Co3+ and Co2+ coexist in cobalt oxides. Fig. 8 shows the H2-TPR profiles of MOR and 7%CoOx/MOR, is reduced in the temperature interval of 150―650 °C. The 7%CoOx/MOR sample exhibits strong and broad peaks, the curve of MOR shows only one broad peak around 238 °C. The H2-TPR curve of 7%CoOx/MOR shows four peaks. The broad peak around 220 °C is caused by MOR support. The strong peak locating at about 368 °C is ascribed to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO. The appearance of the peak at high temperatures of 530 °C and 589 °C is attributable to the reduction of Co2+ interacted strongly with MOR (Table 1 ). 3.2 Catalytic epoxidation of α-pinene Catalytic epoxidation results of α-pinene over various CoOx/zeolite catalysts are demonstrated in Table 2 . Under the same experimental conditions, different catalysts with similar Co content show a sensible difference in the epoxidation of α-pinene. When using 7%CoOx/MOR as the catalyst, the conversion of α-pinene is 92.7 mol% with 87.6% selectivity of epoxide, while 7%CoOx/beta converts 87.6 mol% of α-pinene to 89.7% of epoxide. Although 7%CoOx/Y achieves 84.2 mol% conversion of α-pinene, the selectivity of epoxide is only 80.4%. The catalytic activities of 7%CoOx/ZSM-5, 7%CoOx/13X, 7%CoOx/MCM-22, 7%CoOx/SBA-15 and 7%CoOx/SiO2 are appreciably lower than those of 7%CoOx/MOR and 7%CoOx/Beta. As shown in Table 3 , among various 7%MOx/MOR catalysts, only 7%CoOx/MOR exhibits the best catalytic performance. The use of 7%CoOx/MOR as the catalyst can obtain 92.7 mol% conversion of α-pinene, accompanied with 87.6% selectivity of epoxide; however, other 7%MOx/MOR catalysts achieve very low conversions (<20.1 mol%), much less than that over 7%CoOx/MOR. From Table 3, we can see that cobalt is an effective component of the catalytic epoxidation of α-pinene with oxygen, consistent with our previous works [29,38,39]. As listed in Table 4 , the effect of different synthetic methods on the epoxidation of α-pinene is studied. Over the catalyst obtained by mechanical mixing, the epoxidation conversion of α-pinene and the selectivity of epoxide are 63.4 mol% and 91.9%, respectively. 7%Co-MOR catalyst prepared by ion exchange method obtains 83.3 mol% conversion of α-pinene and 97.2% selectivity of epoxide. Over 7%CoOx/MOR catalyst prepared by microwave heating, the conversion of α-pinene can reach 92.7 mol% with 87.6% selectivity of epoxide. Comparatively, over 7%CoOx/MOR catalyst by traditional heating method, the epoxidation conversion of α-pinene is only 64.2 mol%, with 95.8% selectivity of epoxide. It shows that the 7%CoOx/MOR catalyst prepared by microwaves heating can effectively promote the epoxidation of α-pinene. Fig. S2 compares the effect of different cobalt sources on the epoxidation of α-pinene with air. When cobalt acetate is used as the cobalt source, the epoxidation conversion of α-pinene and the selectivity of epoxide reach 92.7 mol% and 87.6%, respectively. However, when using cobalt sulfate and cobalt chloride as the cobalt sources, lower conversions of 65.5 mol% and 75.1 mol% are obtained, possibly due to the change in the form of CoOx after calcination [40]. To explore the influence of different cobalt content, the effect of different Co loadings on the catalytic activity of CoOx/MOR is studied in Fig. 9 . We investigate the effect of 1%, 3%, 5%, 7% and 10% cobalt loading. With the increase of cobalt loading content, the conversion of α-pinene shows a trend of increasing first and then decreasing. It is found that when the cobalt content is 7%, the conversion of α-pinene reaches the maximum of 92.7 mol% with the epoxide selectivity of 87.6%. When the content of cobalt is increased to 10%, the conversion is reduced. This shows that the excess cobalt loading does not favour the epoxidation of α-pinene with air over CoOx/MOR, possibly associated with the low dispersion of excess CoOx on MOR. The catalytic activity of 7%CoOx/MOR prepared by microwave heating for 0.5, 1, 2, 4 and 6 h for the epoxidation of α-pinene is compared in Fig. S3. As can be seen from the figure, the conversion of α-pinene and the selectivity of epoxide reach 92.7 mol% and 87.6% over the catalyst treated by microwave heating for 4 h, which is the optimal time for boosting the activity of catalyst. Table 5 lists the effect of various solvents on the epoxidation of α-pinene over 7%CoOx/MOR. Obviously, the solvent plays an important role in the epoxidation reactions. The conversion of α-pinene decreases in the sequence of DMF (92.7 mol%) > tetrachloroethane (53.1 mol%) > butyl acetate (31.0 mol%) > cyclohexanone (20.7 mol%) > toluene (6.3 mol%) > acetylacetone (6.0 mol%) > 1,4-dioxane (2.7 mol%). DMF is the most suitable solvent for the selective epoxidation of α-pinene, exactly in line with our previous research results [41–44]. It may be attributed to the strong coordination among DMF, Co2+ and O2 that can promote the activation of O2 molecules to form an active intermediate, which further reacts with α-pinene to produce the epoxidation products. The effect of different oxidants on the activity of 7%CoOx/MOR is compared in Table 6 . Using singular CHP or TBHP as the oxidant achieves 15.7 mol% or 17.8 mol% conversion of α-pinene. Without the addition of CHP or TBHP, dry air or O2 can oxidize 64.9 mol% or 49.8 mol% of α-pinene at 90 °C. When CHP is used as the initiator and pure O2 as the oxidant, a conversion of 55.7 mol% and an epoxide selectivity of 82.9% are obtained. The initiator effect of α-epoxy pinane is poorer than CHP and TBHP. As desired, when CHP or TBHP is used as an initiator, the conversion of α-pinene and the selectivity of epoxide are largely elevated to 92.7 mol% and 87.6% for CHP + air, as well as 82.9 mol% and 95.2% for TBHP + air. The influence of reaction time on the epoxidation of α-pinene over 7%CoOx/MOR is depicted in Fig. 10 . When the reaction time is gradually extended from 1 to 4 h, the conversion of α-pinene tends to increase rapidly. The conversion of α-pinene is 92.7 mol% in 4 h, slowly rise to 93.3 mol% in 5 h, with a little bit increase of the conversion of α-pinene. But the selectivity of epoxide decreases with a further increase of reaction time from 95.2% in 1 h to 85.0% in 5 h. As the reaction time increases, the selectivity of epoxide will decrease, which may be due to further reaction between the active radical intermediate and the epoxidation product. The influence of olefin amount of α-pinene is investigated. It can be observed from Fig. S4 that as the molar content of olefins increases, the conversion of epoxidation gradually decreases. When the olefin content is only 1 mmol, the conversion of α-pinene and selectivity of epoxide is as high as 97.4 mol% and >99.9%. With increasing the olefin content to 3 mmol, the conversion and selectivity are reduced to 93.6 mol% and 95.0%. When the content of α-pinene is 10 mmol, the conversion of α-pinene is 82.6 mol%, and the selectivity of epoxide is only 71.6%. Aside from the catalytic epoxidation of α-pinene with dry air as stated above, Table 7 summarizes the catalytic performance of 7%CoOx/MOR for the epoxidation of various olefins with air. Comparatively, the reactivity of ten olefins decrease in the sequence of α-methylstyrene (99.6 mol% conversion) > α-pinene (92.7 mol%) > styrene (70.0 mol%) > cyclooctene (45.9 mol%) > β-pinene (36.8 mol%) > limonene (28.7 mol%) > 1,5-cyclooctadiene (22.0) > dicyclopentadiene (16.5 mol%) >1-dodecene (6.4 mol%). Totally different from the order of epoxide selectivity of dicyclopentadiene (100% mono-epoxide) = 1-dodecene (100%) = 1,5-cyclooctadiene (100% mono-epoxide) > β-pinene (93.3%) > styrene (92.1%) > cyclooctene (91.4%) > limonene (88.3%) > α-pinene (87.6%) > α-methylstyrene (76.2%). The epoxidation of linear terminal 1-decene with air is negligible because of low π-electron density weakening the ability of electrophilic cycloaddition [45,46]. 4 Conclusions A series of supported CoOx catalysts are prepared by impregnation method while microwave-heating. The experimental results show that the dispersion of CoOx and the loading content of Co have important influences on the conversion of α-pinene and the selectivity of epoxide. The 7%CoOx/MOR catalyst prepared by microwave-heating impregnation method exhibits the highest catalytic performance (92.7 mol% conversion of α-pinene and 87.6% selectivity of epoxide). Under the same experimental conditions, different zeolites with similar Co content show a sensible difference in the epoxidation of α-pinene, and the effects of different synthetic methods on the epoxidation of α-pinene are very big. The effect of different initiators, solvents, reaction time, olefin amount, air flowrate is discussed. The experimental results of the substrate expansion indicate that the catalytic performance of 7%CoOx/MOR for the epoxidation of various olefins have a certain substrate adaptability. coredata.dc:description: CoOx species is firstly introduced onto MOR (Mordenite) by impregnation with microwave heating to catalyze the epoxidation of α-pinene with air. The obtained samples have been characterized by X-ray diffraction, FTIR, SEM, TEM, BET surface area, porosity by N2 adsorption. 7%CoOx/MOR catalyst exhibits remarkably higher activity and selectivity in the epoxidation of α-pinene than that prepared by traditional heating impregnation. The epoxidation conversion of α-pinene over 7%CoOx/MOR prepared by microwave heating reaches 92.7 mol% in 4 h at 90 °C, which is nearly 1.5 times that of the catalyst by traditional impregnation. This is due to the fact that CoOx nanoparticles are produced by microwave heating and uniformly dispersed on MOR.
coredata.dc:title: Enhanced activity of microwave-activated CoOx/MOR catalyst for the epoxidation of α-pinene with air
